required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Rheumatologic Adverse Events and Cancer Immunotherapy
clinical_study.official_title: Rheumatologic Adverse Events and Immunotherapy in Oncology

brief_summary.textblock:
In this study, every patient with cancer who is going to be treated by immunotherapy will fill in a form. In this form, we try to determine if he presents rheumatologic complications of his immunotherapy. If the patient answers yes to one question on the form, the patient will be see in rheumatologic consultation to explore his clinical signs.
The number of patients referred in consultation thanks to this questionnaire will be compared to the number of patients who would have been spontaneously referred by the oncologist.
The aim of this questionnaire is to optimise the management of rheumatological effects secondary to immunotherapy.

primary_outcome.measure: to determine whether a self-questionnaire completed by a patient treated with immunotherapy can identify more patients with rheumatological side effects related to this treatment, compared to the complaint reported by the patient to the oncologist
primary_outcome.description: number of patients referred to a rheumatology consultation thanks to the answers to the questionnaire compared to the number of patients referred to a consultation (from questionnaire and oncologist)

arm_group.description: All patients starting immunotherapy treatment will complete a questionnaire to identify rheumatological side effects, each time they come for treatment.

intervention.description: Patient will have to fill in a form at each perfusion of immunotherapy to tell if they presents rheumatologic clinical signs

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient with cancer needed to be treated by immunotherapy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient already treated by immunotherapy

condition_browse.mesh_term: Drug-Related Side Effects and Adverse Reactions
